course.subject: COMP
course.name: Foundations of Computer Vision
course.description: This course provides a comprehensive introduction to computer vision. Major topics include image processing, detection and recognition, geometry-based and physics-based vision and video analysis. Instructor's approval is required for enrollment in the course.
course.prerequisites: (COMP 3711 OR COMP 3711H) AND (MATH 2111 OR MATH 2121)

reviews.author: Argen
reviews.title: Hardest UG Course, Arena of Top Students (CGA Cutoff 3.5)
reviews.comment_content:
TL;DR; Hard and lengthy. A lot of Math.

Different to COMP4901J/COMP4471, this course includes computer vision techniques that both learning and non-learning based. Most of the parts have heavy dependence on Math.

Just like CK's other courses, the content is a direct copy of the material of other universities:
http://www.cs.cmu.edu/~16385/

In case the link is dead, here lists the topics:
1. Image filtering
2. Image pyramids and (some) Fourier transform
3. Hough transform
4. Corner detection
5. Feature descriptors and matching
6. 2D transformations
7. Image homographies
8. Camera models
9. Two-view geometry
10. Stereo
11. Structure from motion
12. Radiometry and reflectance
13. Photometric stereo and shape from shading
14. Introduction to recognition
15. Bag of words
16. Neural networks
17. Convolutional neural network
18. Optical flow
19. Alignment and tracking
20. Graph-based methods

Yes, as you can see, a terribly long list of content, and there are ~200 slides in each topic.
reviews.comment_teaching:
CK speaks rapidly but in a stammering way. It can be hard to understand. And eventually you will get used to it.

The real challenge is not his English, but the content. He expects you have a strong CV sense and understand things super quickly. He did not stop at one point explaining things until clear, but skipped as long as he could.

If you are not genius, I would recommend you spend some time preparing before the lecture.
reviews.comment_grading:
72% - 6 project assignments
28% - Final Exam

As we were unable to have on-campus teaching and exam in late November, it became
100% - 7 project assignments (with bonus)

Intake Requirement
CGA cutoff: ~3.5
Good grades in Math courses
mean CGA: ~3.8

As most of the students are already A rankers, CK gave >50% A range. You'll get an A easily if you score almost full mark in all assignments and complete all bonuses.
reviews.comment_workload:
The workload is pretty heavy.

You have 2 weeks for each project assignment. They usually compose of a theory part with short questions and a programming part requiring you to write several Matlab scripts. You can either form a group of 2 or work individually for project assignments. I chose to cope with them individually, and each assignment costs me ~2/3 full days.

but cant learn much from him since he spent less than 1 minute on each slide in average
and the slides are not well organized,
the descriptions of assignments are unclear
the grading guidelines of assignments are vague

but when i ask for clarification the respond is quite fast and able to answer my question, however, this does not apply to my friends
